Physical protection should be provided to prevent heat sources such as steam lines, air lines, electrical motors and mechanical drive equipment from becoming buried or heavily coated with combustible material. (Ord. of 3-28-2017, § 1) Sec. 42-69. - Material-handling equipment and vehicles. Material-handling equipment or scoop-type vehicles, as approved by the director, shall be available at every site for moving wood chips, hogged material, wood fines and raw product during firefighting operations. All vehicles shall be garaged in separate detached buildings or parked in designated areas located at least 50 feet from chipping or hogging operations or storage. All fuel handling shall be done in accordance with applicable provisions of the Fire Code. (Ord. of 3-28-2017, § 1) Sec. 42-70. - Storage and operations inside of a building. Storage and operations inside of a building shall be in accordance with Fire Code. (Ord. of 3-28-2017, § 1)

div.head: Chapter 50 - HEALTH AND SAFETY[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Animals, ch. 14; rabies control, §§ 14-61 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 38; flood hazard prevention, ch. 46; manufactured homes and mobile homes, ch. 54; solid waste, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 90. State Law reference— Promulgation of rules, regulations and standards for food service establishments by state department of human resources and county boards of health, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-373; health generally, O.C.G.A. §§ 31-1-1 et seq.; power of county board of health to adopt and enforce rules and regulations, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-4(a)(4); power of county board of health to adopt rules and regulations of local application, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-6; county board of health generally, §§ 31-3-1 et seq.
Sec. 50-1. - Health department fees. Charges for health department services shall be in amounts as established and amended from time to time by the director of the health department, upon the written approval of the chairman of the board of commissioners and the chief of operations; provided, however, that the amount of such fees shall be presented within the annual budget approved by the board of commissioners. In the event that the position of director of the health department is vacant, the amount of the fees may be established and amended from time to time by the chief of operations, upon the written approval of the chairman of the board of commissioners; provided, however, that the amount of such fees shall be presented within the annual budget approved by the board of commissioners. (Code 1993, § 11-1; Mo. of 6-23-1998; Mo. of 11-23-1999; Mo. of 6-26-2001; Mo. of 3-25-2003; Ord. of 1-25-2005; Ord. of 5-10-2005) Sec. 50-2. - Emergency medical services fees. Charges for emergency medical services shall be in amounts as established and amended from time to time by the director of the emergency medical services department, upon the written approval of the chairman of the board of commissioners and the chief of operations; provided, however, that the amount of such fees shall be presented within the annual budget approved by the board of commissioners. In the event that the position of director of the emergency medical services department is vacant, the amount of the fees may be established and amended from time to time by the chief of operations, upon the written approval of the chairman of the board of commissioners; provided, however, that the amount of such fees shall be presented within the annual budget approved by the board of commissioners. (Code 1993, § 11-2; Mo. of 6-9-1998; Ord. of 5-10-2005) Sec. 50-3. - Emergency Communications—Telephone charge. (a) The county has an enhanced emergency telephone number 911 (E-911) system countywide. (b) In accord with O.C.G.A. §§ 46-5-133(a) and 46-5-134(a)(1)(A) and (a)(2)(B), the necessity for the "9-1-1" and the wireless enhanced "9-1-1" charges is hereby affirmed, and the maximum allowable fee rates are set at a rate not to exceed $1.50 per month: 1) per telephone service subscribed to by telephone subscribers whose exchange access lines are in the areas served or which would be served by the county's emergency communications service; and 2) per each wireless telecommunications connection, other than a connection for prepaid wireless service, subscribed to by telephone subscribers whose place of primary use is within the geographic area that is served by the county or that would be served by the county for the purpose of the county's emergency communications system. (c) All acts and doings of the officers of the county which are in conformity with the purposes and intents of this section and in the furtherance of the implementation of the emergency communications system shall be, and the same hereby are, in all respects approved and confirmed. (Code 1993, § 8-8; Res. of 5-25-1999; Res. of 2-24-2009; Ord. of 3-22-2011) Editor's note— For the purposes of classification, § 50-3 hereof was relocated from § 30-4 at the discretion of the editor. State Law reference— Georgia Emergency Telephone Number 911 Service Act of 1977, O.C.G.A. §§ 46-5-120 et seq. Sec. 50-4. - Same—Advisory board. (a) Creation. The government of Barrow County hereby creates the Barrow County 911 Advisory Board in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 45-5-136. (b) Membership. The membership shall consist of individuals knowledgeable of the 911 communications system, representatives from other public safety agencies which respond to emergency communications calls under the system, and other individuals knowledgeable of emergency communications systems and the emergency needs of the citizens of Barrow County, provided that the advisory board not exceed 13 members. (c) Composition. The following public safety/support agencies shall be represented on the advisory board: (1) Barrow County Board of Commissioners Chairperson/or appointee. (2) City of Auburn Mayor. (3) Town of Carl Mayor. (4) Town of Bethlehem Mayor. (5) Town of Braselton Mayor. (6) City of Stratham Mayor. (7) City of Winder Mayor. (8) Barrow County Sheriff. (9) Barrow County Chief of Emergency Services. (10) City of Statham Chief of Police. (11) City of Auburn Chief of Police. (12) City of Winder Chief of Police. (13) City of Winder Fire Chief. (d) Meetings. The 911 advisory board shall meet on a quarterly basis, or more frequently as needed. The chairperson of the board of commissioners or their appointee shall be chairperson of the emergency communications advisory board. (e) Duties. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-236, the governing authority of Barrow County does hereby create by resolution the Barrow County 911 Advisory Board and authorizes this board to assist the local government in the following duties: (1) Review and analyze the progress of public safety agencies in developing their emergency communications system requirements as needed for an effective public safety communications system. (2) Recommend steps of action to effect the necessary coordination, regulation and development of an emergency communications system. (3) Identify mutual aid agreements and standard operating procedures necessary for an efficient communication system to serve the local government. (4) Assist in the promulgation of necessary rules, regulations, operating procedures, schedules, and other such policies and administrative devices as shall be deemed necessary and appropriate; and (5) Provide other services as may be deemed appropriate by the local government. (f) Compensation. The members of the advisory board shall not be compensated from moneys deposited into the "emergency telephone system fund." (g) Funding. Funding shall be appropriated from the general fund of Barrow County on an annual basis. (h) Amendments. The duties of the advisory board may be amended, as needed, by Barrow County authorities and subject to change by O.C.G.A. section as amended. (Ord. of 5-24-2005; Ord. of 3-22-2011; Ord. of 4-12-2011) Sec. 50-5. - Mutual aid resource pact. (a) Barrow County Department of Emergency Services may render aid and assistance during disastrous incidents and other immediate response emergencies outside its jurisdiction. (b) Department of emergency services may form a mutual aid resource pact, known as the Georgia Mutual Aid Group, with other jurisdictions, as defined on O.C.G.A. §§ 25-6-1 et seq., the Georgia Mutual Aid Group being a public corporation. (c) The Georgia Mutual Aid Group shall be governed by O.C.G.A. §§ 25-6-1 et seq. (d) The department of emergency services chief or his/her designee shall be authorized to act on behalf of the fire and emergency services all matters relating to the activities and functions of the mutual aid resource pact once it has been established. (e) Department of emergency services may withdraw from the Georgia Mutual Aid Group by resolution and vote of the Barrow County Board of Commissioners pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 25-6-1 et seq. (f) Department of emergency services liabilities, privileges, and immunities, including those of its firefighters and other persons acting on its behalf, shall be governed by O.C.G.A. §§ 25-6-1 et seq. (Ord. of 12-13-2005; Ord. of 3-22-2011) Sec. 50-6. - Local emergency operations plan. (a) The board of commissioners does hereby adopt the updated local emergency operations plan. (b) The plan shall be maintained by Barrow County Emergency Services and the chief shall deliver a copy of Resolution of 12-11-2012 and the plan to the Georgia Emergency Management Agency. (c) The chief of emergency services shall periodically update the appendixes to the annex as necessary. Appendix updates will not require further adoption by the board of commissioners. (Res. of 12-11-2012, §§ 1—3) Editor's note— Res. of 12-11-2012, §§ 1—3, set out provisions that were not specifically amendatory to the Code. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 50-6. Sec. 50-7. - Safety coordinator. The safety coordinator will be responsible for insuring compliance with certain safety rules and regulations that protect the well-being of county employees and the general public. The safety coordinator will be responsible for: (1) Establishing and coordinating safety meetings and self inspections to identify safety related hazards; (2) Coordinating and implementing safety rules and training for supervisors and employees and/or making recommendations to management regarding such items; (3) Reviewing and/or investigating all employee accidents for causes and making recommendations for improvements and corrections; (4) Conducting periodic safety self inspections of all vehicles, buildings, grounds, equipment and machinery, and work practices and conditions to determine potential injury exposures; (5) Documenting and maintaining inspections records and implementing any follow-up actions. The safety coordinator will ensure that qualifications have been met that will enable the county to receive substantial discounts on their insurance costs. (Res. of 5-14-2013) Editor's note— Res. of 5-14-2013 set out provisions that were not specifically amendatory to the Code. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 50-7.

div.head: Chapter 54 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND MOBILE HOMES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 38; flood hazard prevention, ch. 46; health, ch. 50; planning and development, ch. 66; roads, ch. 70; solid waste, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 90; zoning, app. A; mobile home park district (R-4), app. A, art. IV, div. 6. State Law reference— Ad valorem taxation of mobile homes, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-5-440 et seq.; The Uniform Standards Code for Manufactured Homes Act, O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-130 et seq.; classification of mobile homes as a separate class of property for ad valorem property tax purposes, Ga. Const. art. VII, § I, ¶ III; factory-built buildings and dwelling units, O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-110 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 54-1—54-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LOCATION PERMIT[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Issuance of mobile home location permits, display of decals, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-492.
Sec. 54-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Mobile home means a detached single-family dwelling designed for longterm occupancy, designed to be transported on its own wheels, arriving at the site as a complete dwelling unit usually including major appliances and furniture, and ready for occupancy; which dwelling has been constructed in accordance with the Federal Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards of June 15, 1976, as amended, and bears an insignia issued by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. Removal of the wheels and placement of this dwelling on a foundation does not change its classification. A travel trailer is not a manufactured home. (Code 1993, § 14-26) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 54-32. - Intent of article. It is the intent of this article to provide requirements whereby the officials of the county shall accurately prepare and check tax returns on mobile homes and collect all applicable taxes due on mobile homes. (Code 1993, § 14-27) Sec. 54-33. - Administration. (a) The board of commissioners will prepare and furnish to the tax commissioner the necessary supplies and forms as may be necessary to effectively carry out the provisions of this article. (b) The board of commissioners will prepare necessary rules and regulations for the tax commissioner to follow to effectively carry out the provisions of this article. (Code 1993, § 14-28) Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. Sec. 54-34. - Penalties; impoundment. (a) Any person failing to comply with or violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as for a misdemeanor; provided, however, that a person convicted under this article shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00. (b) Any law enforcement officer who finds a mobile home being transported within the confines of the county in violation of this article may have such mobile home and the vehicle transporting such mobile home impounded at the owner's risk and expense until a permit for such transportation is issued. (c) Any person transporting a mobile home which does not have the appropriate decal affixed as required by this article shall be in violation of this article, and upon conviction under this article shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00. (Code 1993, § 14-29) Sec. 54-35. - Authorization of location by building official; location permit required. (a) The owner of a mobile home, before locating a mobile home within the confines of the county, intending to use such mobile home as a residence for himself or others or for any other purpose other than resale, shall obtain from the building permit office of the county a permit authorizing the location of such mobile home within the confines of the county. Such person shall obtain from the tax commissioner a location permit, thereby registering such mobile home on county tax records. (b) The owner of such mobile home, before relocating such mobile home within the confines of the county, or beyond the confines of the county, intending to use such mobile home as a residence or for any other purpose other than resale, must obtain a permit from the building permit office. Such person shall also obtain from the tax commissioner a location permit, thereby registering such mobile home on county tax records. (Code 1993, § 14-30) Sec. 54-36. - Payment of taxes. (a) All applicable taxes must be paid before any permit provided for in this article shall be issued. (b) Before any permit provided for in this article shall be issued, the owner of a mobile home, which home is located within any portion of the county that lies within a municipality, shall furnish proof to the tax commissioner that all applicable municipal taxes have been paid. (Code 1993, § 14-31) Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82. Sec. 54-37. - Decals. (a) The tax commissioner shall issue a decal, at the time a building permit is issued under this article, authorizing the location of a mobile home in the county. The decal shall be of a color that is approved each year by the department of revenue and shall be affixed by the owner to the mobile home at all times it is being used as a residence within the county, or for any purpose other than resale. (b) The tax commissioner shall issue a decal, in a color approved by the department of revenue, with the permit authorizing relocation of a mobile home, which shall be affixed to the mobile home at all times such mobile home is being transported within the county and the state. (c) The decals shall be designed in such manner and affixed to mobile homes in such manner as to cause them to be easily visible for inspection. Whenever a permit authorizing relocation of a mobile home is issued and such mobile home is to be relocated within the confines of another county of this state, the tax assessors of such other county shall be notified of the date of the issuance of such permit. (Code 1993, § 14-32) Sec. 54-38. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. of May 10, 2005, repealed § 54-38, which pertained to the permit fee and derived from Code 1993, § 14-33.

div.head: Chapter 58 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Courts, ch. 34; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. State Law reference— Violation of county ordinances, O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-60 et seq.; Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-1-1 et seq.; authority to adopt ordinances for the purpose of preserving public health, safety and welfare, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20; limitation on home rule powers of municipal corporations with respect to duplication of state criminal offenses, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 58-1. - Applicability of chapter. It shall be unlawful for any person within the unincorporated areas of the county to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. (Code 1993, § 15.5-1) Sec. 58-2. - Loitering or prowling. (a) No person shall loiter or prowl. (b) A person commits the offense of loitering or prowling when he is in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals and under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. (c) Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this chapter, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the procedure as stated in this subsection or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. (d) A person committing the offense of loitering or prowling shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. (Code 1993, § 15.5-2) State Law reference— Loitering or prowling, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-36. Sec. 58-3. - Disorderly conduct. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person within the unincorporated areas of the county to engage in any conduct described in the following subsections. (1) To act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any person is placed in fear of the safety of his life, limb or health. (2) To act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being damaged or destroyed. (3) To cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another. (4) To assemble or congregate with another or others for the purpose of or with the intent to engage in gaming. (5) To be in or about any place, alone or with another or others, with the purpose of or intent to engage in any fraudulent scheme, trick or device to obtain any money or valuable thing; or to aid or abet any person in doing so. (6) To be in or about any place where gaming or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated, for the purpose of or intent to engage in gaming or the purchase, use, possession or consumption of such illegal drugs, narcotics or alcoholic beverages. (7) To direct "fighting words" toward another, that is, words which by their very nature tend to incite a breach of the peace. (8) To interfere, by acts of physical obstruction, with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation. (9) To congregate with another or others in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and to fail to clear the public way after being ordered to do so by a county sheriff's deputy or other lawful authority. (10) To disrupt, by actions which tend to incite a breach of peace, the activities of any house of worship, hospital or home for the elderly or any lawful meeting, gathering or procession. (11) To throw bottles, paper, cans, glass, sticks, stones, missiles or any other debris on public property. (b) Enforcement. This section shall be enforceable by all law enforcement personnel duly ordained and empowered to enforce the laws and ordinances in the county. (c) Jurisdiction of magistrate court. The magistrate court of the county shall have jurisdiction to try the offenses described in this section. (Ord. No. 11-11-1997, § 2(15.5-3), (15.5-4), (15.5-6)) Sec. 58-4. - Noise. (a) Definitions. For purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: Highway: Defined as in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1(19), which is incorporated by reference as if fully set forth in this section. Noise: Any sound that is excessive in volume, frequency or duration as would disrupt the peace and quiet reasonable people with ordinary sensibilities. Sounds that are plainly audible to a person of normal hearing ability from the distance of 50 feet from the point of origin shall be presumed to be "noise" in violation of this section. Private property: Any dwelling, house, building or other structure, whether inhabited or used permanently or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant and which is 100 percent privately owned and shall include any real property, yard, grounds, walk, parking area, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or any portion or addition thereof belonging or pertinent to such dwelling, house, building or structure or any land, area or lot that does not have an existing structure within the boundaries of the property. Public place means any area that is used or held out for use by the public, whether owned or operated by public or private interests, including but not limited to streets, parking lots parking garages, sidewalks, rights-of-way, parks, campgrounds, highways, alleys and other public ways. (b) Prohibited noise. No person shall yell, shout, sing, chant, or make any other loud or raucous noises by any means whatsoever, whether by voice, hand-clapping, stomping or mechanical means, in a manner which constitutes "noise" as defined in this section. This section and its prohibitions shall apply equally to noise that originates and/or is heard on public property, private property (whether it be office, commercial, industrial, agricultural, or residential), and on the highways of the county or in proximity thereto. Such sounds which are audible to a person with normal hearing ability from the distance of 50 feet from the point of origin are presumed to be "noise" in violation of this section. For purposes of this section, such mechanical sound includes, but is not limited to, the usage of firearms or pyrotechnics, the production of sound caused by the construction, destruction, or maintenance of any building, dwelling or structure, the building or maintenance of any mechanical contrivance, including motor vehicles, common lawn equipment and agricultural machinery, or the operation of any mechanical device. The following acts among others are declared to be per se in violation of this section, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: (1) Horns, signaling devices. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle on any street or public place in the county, except as a danger warning; the creation of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound by means of this signaling device and the sounding of this device for an unreasonable period of time; the use of any signaling device, except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust and the use of this signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up is prohibited. (2) Radios, phonographs, similar devices. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to unreasonably disturb the peace, quiet, repose of reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities or at any time with louder volume than is reasonably necessary for convenient hearing for the person who is in the room, vehicle or chamber in which this machine or device is operated and who is a voluntary listener thereto. The operation of the set, instrument, phonograph machine or device between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the origin of sound produced shall be presumed to be a violation of this section. (3) Loudspeakers, amplifiers for advertising. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used, or operated of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other device for producing or reproducing sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure is prohibited. Such announcements over loudspeakers shall only be made by the announcer in person and without the aid of any mechanical device. (4) Yelling, shouting and the like. Yelling, shouting, hooting whistling or singing, particularly between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to unreasonably disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities is prohibited. Such noise that is plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the origin of sound shall be presumed to be in violation of this section. (5) Noisy animals or birds. Anyone who keeps or maintains an animal or bird that unreasonably disturbs the comfort or repose of any reasonable person with ordinary sensibilities, because the animal or bird is emitting frequent or long continued sound or noise, and who continues to keep, maintain, or allow any animal or bird to so disturb the comfort or repose of any reasonable person with ordinary sensibilities shall be deemed in violation of this section, provided that the person keeping or maintaining the animal or bird has been first notified in writing by certified mail, return receipt requested, by the complaining party that this animal or bird being kept by the addressee is unreasonably disturbing his or her comfort or repose. This section shall be liberally construed to accomplish the objective of the section, and the person making this written notification need not use the exact words of this section to the addressee so long as the notification sufficiently informs the addressee of the nature of the disturbing noise emitted by the animal or bird. Upon receipt of a certified letter notifying the person keeping or maintaining such animal or bird, such person shall be required to immediately comply with this section. This section shall not apply to horses, livestock, poultry or other farm animals, provided the sound is emanating from a legitimate farming operation on property that is properly zoned for such use. (6) Construction or repair of buildings. The erection, excavating, demolition, alteration or repair of any building other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 11 p.m. on weekdays shall be prohibited, except when the Barrow County Building Inspector deems on-site situation warrants an extended time. The Barrow County Building Inspector may grant a special permit extending this time which is not to exceed ten working days for this work to be done between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. (7) Transportation of metal rails, similar materials. The transportation of rails, pillars or columns of iron, steel or other material over and along streets and other public places upon carts, drays, cars, trucks or in any manner so loaded as to cause unreasonably loud noises or as to unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of reasonable persons with ordinary sensibilities is prohibited. (8) Pile drivers, hammers, and similar equipment. The operation between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of this type tool shall be prohibited. Included in this category, but not limited to, is steam shovel, pneumatic hammers derricks, steam or electric hoist, fork lifts and the like. (9) Blowers and motors. The operation of any noise-creating blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noises due to explosion of operating gases or fluids is prohibited, unless the noise from this blower or fan is muffled and the engine is equipped with a muffler device specifically designed for the type engine and is not adapted, altered or make-shift and provides reasonable sufficiency in muffling the engine noise. (10) Sound trucks. The use of sound trucks for noncommercial purposes with such unreasonable volume as to disturb the peace and quiet of reasonable persons with ordinary sensibilities is prohibited. Such sound that is plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the origin of sound shall be presumed to be a violation of this section. (11) Steam whistles. Any steam whistle attached to a stationary boiler is prohibited, except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger upon request of proper authorities. (12) Exhausts. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine or motor vehicle or boat is prohibited, except through a muffler which is specifically designed for the type engine and is not adapted, altered or make-shift, providing reasonable sufficiency in muffling engine noise. a. All engines for the purpose of racing, be it car, motorcycle, truck or go-cart shall be equipped with approved racing mufflers and shall cease operation on Monday through Friday between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. and shall further cease operations on Saturday and Sunday between the hours of 11:30 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Moreover, the operators and owners of any racing facility shall be responsible for racing participants being in compliance with muffler usage and the other provisions of this section and shall be subject to enforcement under this section for failure to so control racing participants. (13) Defect in vehicle or load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create unreasonably loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, ratting or other noises so as to disturb the peace and quiet of reasonable persons with ordinary sensibilities are prohibited. Such sound that is plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the origin of sound shall be presumed to be a violation of this section. (14) Schools, courts, churches, hospitals. The creation of any unreasonably excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same are in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the normal operation of the institution, or which disturbs reasonable persons with ordinary sensibilities is prohibited, provided that conspicuous signs are displayed in the streets indicating that is a school, hospital or court street. Sound that is plainly audible inside the institution shall be presumed to be a violation of this section. (15) Hawkers, peddlers, vendors. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of reasonable persons with ordinary sensibilities is prohibited. Such sound that is plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the origin of sound shall be presumed to be a violation of this section. (16) Noises to attract attention. The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention to any performance, show car sale, or the like so as to disturb reasonable persons with ordinary sensibilities is prohibited. Such sound that is plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the origin of sound shall be presumed to be a violation of this section. (17) Operation of motor vehicles. The operation of motor vehicles, including, but not limited to, cars, trucks, motorcycles, all-terrain vehicles, and mopeds, upon any parking facility, public or private, vehicle access or pedestrian walkway, or street, public or private, so as to create unreasonable noise and to disturb the peace, quiet and repose of reasonable persons with ordinary sensibilities is prohibited. Such sound that is plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the origin of sound shall be presumed to be a violation of this section. The operation of motor vehicles which employ Jakebrakes that are used in a manner to cause unnecessary noise is prohibited. (c) Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to or be enforced against: (1) Any vehicle of the county while engaged in necessary public business. (2) Excavations or repairs of streets by or on behalf of the county or state at night when public welfare and convenience renders it impossible to perform this work during the day. (3) Organized school-related programs, activities, events or parades or other public programs, activities or events authorized by the county or sheriff's office. (4) Noise resulting from emergency work, to be construed to mean work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, or work required to protect persons or property from imminent exposure to danger. (5) Noise emanating from approved construction sites associated with reasonable construction activities, provided that the noise occurs only during daylight hours and does not disturb reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities who are nearby residents. (6) Noise emanating from commercial, industrial, or manufacturing districts, provided that the noise occurs only during daylight hours and does not disturb reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities and the business producing such noises are properly permitted. (7) Noise associated with hunting activities, provided that the hunting activities are occurring on land properly zoned for such activities and provided that all activities are in conformance with applicable law. (d) Special variances: (1) The board of commissioners shall have the authority, consistent with this section, to grant variances. (2) Any person seeking a variance pursuant to this section shall file an application with the director of license and permits (the "director"). The application shall contain information that demonstrates that bringing the source of sound into compliance with this section would constitute an unreasonable hardship on the applicant, on the community, or on other persons. The director shall give notice of an application for a special variance to persons who frequent the area of the sound or activity and who may be adversely affected by the granting of the variance by posting the property and by letter to adjoining property owners. Any individual who claims to be adversely affected by allowances of the variance may file a statement with the director within ten days of receiving notice of the special variance request, which statement should contain any information to support such individual's claim. The director shall forward the application and any responsive statements to the board of commissioners for its consideration. (3) In determining whether to grant or deny the application, the board of commissioners shall balance the hardship to the applicant, the community, and other persons of not granting the special variance against the adverse impact on the health, safety, and welfare of other persons affected by the granting of the special variance. The variance request will also be otherwise considered by the board of commissioners under the variance standards set forth in the Barrow County Zoning and Development Regulations, which regulations are incorporated herein by reference as if fully set forth herein. (4) Applicants for special variances may be required to submit any information the board of commissioners may reasonably require for its consideration of the request. (5) In granting or denying an application, the board of commissioners shall place on public file, a copy of the decision and reasons for denying or granting the special variance. (6) Special variances shall be granted by notice to the applicant containing all necessary conditions, including a time limit on the permitted activity. The special variance shall not become effective until the applicant agrees to all conditions. Noncompliance with any condition of the special variance shall terminate the special variance and subject the person holding it to those provisions of this section regulating the source of sound or activity for which the special variance was granted. (7) Application for extension of time limits specified in special variances or for modification of other substantial conditions shall be treated like applications for initial special variances. (8) Enforcement of this article shall be stayed as to any person filing an application for a special variance pursuant to this section, until such time as the board of commissioners acts upon the application. (9) The decision of the board of commissioners is final. (10) Special events, including but not limited to carnivals, fairs, tent meetings, revivals, rallies, festivals, concerts or any public gathering, whether for the purpose of disseminating information, entertainment or political speech, must have a special variance to be exempted from this section. (e) Enforcement; penalty. (1) This section shall be enforceable by all law enforcement personnel duly ordained and empowered to enforce the laws and ordinances in the county. If a violation is construed as a moving traffic violation, the Barrow County Sheriff's Office shall be responsible for enforcement and shall be responsible for enforcement when responding to a complaint or when a vehicle in violation may be tracked through use of a tag search and cited for the violation at a fixed location. (2) Any person found in violation of any of the provisions of this section shall be found guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine of not less than $250.00 and not more than $1,000.00 or be imprisoned in the county jail or correctional institution for a period not to exceed 60 days or both, for each offense for which the offender is convicted. (3) For purposes of this section, each day that a violation is committed or permitted shall be punishable as a separate offense. In addition, each subsequent occasion on which a law enforcement officer must respond to the same incident after an initial citation is written shall be considered a separate offense, regardless of whether the later responses occur on the same day as the first citation. (f) Jurisdiction of magistrate court. The Magistrate Court of Barrow County shall have jurisdiction to try the offenses described in this section. (Ord. of 11-11-1997, § 2(15.5-5), (15.5-6); Ord. of 1-11-2005(1)) Sec. 58-5. - Alarm systems. (a) Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the respective meaning ascribed to them by this section: Alarm means any signal (audio or visual, recorded or live) transmitted to the county, indicating a predetermined condition exists when said alarm is received either by: a. Telephone line to the county 911 communications center; b. A private alarm service company relayed to the county 911 communications center's telephones; c. An automated telephone alarm system, playing a recorded message when received on the county 911 communications center's telephones; or d. An audible/visual signal relayed to the county 911 communications center by a third party. False alarm means the activation of an alarm system where none of the emergencies for which the alarm system has been installed, have in fact occurred. Response means the dispatch of any law enforcement or fire unit to the premises where an alarm has been activated. Telephone alarm system means any alarm system which automatically transmits by telephone line a recorded electronic or mechanical signal to a telephone instrument at the county 911 communications center is prohibited. (b) Automatic dialing systems. The installation and operation of equipment that will automatically dial in an alarm to the county 911 communications center is prohibited. This does not include professional alarm companies that are supervised 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. (c) Prohibitions. It shall be unlawful for anyone to activate any robbery, burglary, or fire alarm except in the event of an actual or attempted burglary, robbery or fire. It shall be unlawful for anyone to notify the county of an activated alarm with the knowledge that such activation was caused by an electrical or other malfunction of the system or by lack of adequate maintenance of the alarm system without at the same time notifying the law enforcement of such apparent malfunctions. (d) Service fees imposed. (1) For each response to a false alarm, a report shall be made and forwarded to the marshal's office. The chief fire marshal or his/her designee shall take the following actions: a. For the first false alarm from a premises within a six-month period, the marshal shall forward to the property owner or premises lessee a copy of the report, a copy of this chapter, and a statement that continued false alarms will lead to a service fee; b. For the second false alarm from a premises within a 12-month period, the marshal shall suggest the alarm system to be inspected by a state licensed alarm low voltage contractor and to prescribe necessary corrective action (this will be done at the owner's expense); c. For the third false alarm within a 12-month period, the property owner or lessee shall be charged a fee of $50.00; and d. For the fourth false alarm and all succeeding alarms within a 12-month period, the property owner or lessee shall be charged a fee up to $100.00 per alarm and each additional alarm thereafter. (2) The chief fire marshal or his/her designee shall be responsible for issuing citations for fees imposed. (3) The false alarm shall not be considered for purposes of assessing a fee if: a. Within ten days from the occurrence of a false alarm, the owner or lessee of the premises can demonstrate to the sheriff, as applicable, that the alarm system in question has actually been examined by an authorized repair service who certifies in writing that the system is currently in good working order; provided, however, no more than one letter may be submitted by an owner or lessee within a six-month period in order to avoid a fee assessment; b. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no more than one such letter may be submitted by an owner or lessee of a premises within a 12-month period in order to avoid a fee assessment as provided by this paragraph; or c. The alarm was activated by inclement weather. (Ord. of 6-13-2000; Res. of 2-24-2004) Sec. 58-6. - Public drunkenness. It shall be unlawful for any person to be and appear in an intoxicated condition in any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant, when such condition is made manifest by boisterousness, by indecent condition or act, or by vulgar, profane, loud, or unbecoming language. (Res. of 11-24-2009) Secs. 58-7—58-36. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— A Resolution adopted April 28, 2009, §§ 1—1.12, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion as Ch. 58, Art. II, §§ 58-37—58-48 was at the discretion of the editor.
DIVISION 1. - RED FLAG RULES
Sec. 58-37. - Short title. This resolution shall be known as the "Identity Theft Prevention Program." (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.1) Sec. 58-38. - Purpose. The purpose of this resolution is to comply with 16 CFR § 681.2 in order to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.2) Sec. 58-39. - Definitions. For purposes of this resolution, the following definitions apply: 'County' means Barrow County, Georgia. 'Covered account' means: (i) an account that a financial institution or creditor offers or maintains, primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, that involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions, such as a credit card account, mortgage loan, automobile loan, margin account, cell phone account, utility account, checking account, or savings account; and (ii) any other account that the financial institution or creditor offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the financial institution or creditor from identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation, or litigation risks. ' Credit' means the right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and defer payment therefore. 'Creditor' means any person who regularly extends, renews, or continues credit; any person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal, or continuation of credit; or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the decision to extend, renew, or continue credit and includes utility companies and telecommunications companies. 'Customer' means a person who has a covered account with the county. 'Identity theft' means a fraud committed or attempted using identifying information of another person without authority. 'Person' means a natural person, a corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency, trust, estate, partnership, cooperative, or association. 'Personal identifying information' means a person's credit card account information, debit card information bank account information and drivers' license information and for a natural person includes their social security number, mother's birth name, and date of birth. 'Program' shall mean the Identity Theft Prevention Program implemented by this resolution. 'Red flag' means a pattern, practice, or specific activity that indicates the possible existence of identity theft. 'Service provider' means a person that provides a service directly to the county. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.3) Sec. 58-40. - Findings. (a) The county is a creditor pursuant to 16 CFR § 681.2 due to its provision or maintenance of covered accounts for which payment is made in arrears. (b) Covered accounts offered to customers for the provision of county services are limited to water/sewer services. (c) The county is aware of previous suspected instances of potential identity theft related to covered accounts. (d) The processes of opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account, making payments on such accounts have been identified as potential processes in which identity theft could occur. (e) The county limits access to personal identifying information to those employees responsible for or otherwise involved in opening or restoring covered accounts or accepting payment for use of covered accounts. Beginning no later than January 1, 2010, information provided to such employees will be entered directly into the county's computer system and will not be otherwise recorded. (f) The county determines that there is a risk of identity theft occurring in the following ways: (1) Use by an applicant of another person's personal identifying information to establish a new covered account; (2) Use of a previous customer's personal identifying information by another person in an effort to have service restored in the previous customer's name; (3) Use of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment by a customer to pay such customer's covered account or accounts; (4) Use by a customer desiring to restore such customer's covered account of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.4) Sec. 58-41. - Process of establishing a covered account. (a) As a precondition to opening a covered account in the county, county personnel will take reasonable steps including but not limited to the following to obtain and verify the identity of the person opening the account: (1) Require identifying information such as name, date of birth, residential or business address, principal place of business for a business entity, driver's license or other valid government issued photo identification. (2) Verify the customer's identity by reviewing documentation provided. (3) Review documentation showing the existence of a business entity. (4) Confirm residential service addresses. (5) Independently contact the customer. Such information shall be entered directly into the county's computer system and shall not otherwise be recorded. (b) Each account shall be assigned an account number and may include a personal identification number ("PIN") which shall be unique to that account. The county may utilize computer software to randomly generate assigned PINs and to encrypt account numbers and PINs. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.5) Sec. 58-42. - Access to covered account information. (a) Access to customer accounts shall be password protected and shall be limited to authorized county personnel. (b) Such password(s) shall be changed by the chairman or his/her designee on a regular basis, shall be at least eight characters in length and shall contain letters, numbers and symbols. (c) Any unauthorized access to or other breach of customer accounts is to be reported immediately to the chairman or his/her designee and the password(s) changed immediately. (d) Personal identifying information included in customer accounts is considered confidential and any request or demand for such information shall be immediately forwarded to the chairman or his/her designee and the county attorney. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.6) Sec. 58-43. - Credit card payments. (a) In the event that credit card payments that are made over the Internet are processed through a third party service provider, such third party service provider shall certify, in writing, to the county that it has an adequate identity theft prevention program in place that is applicable to such payments. (b) All credit card payments made over the telephone or the county's website shall be entered directly into the customer's account information in the computer database. (c) Account statements and receipts for covered accounts shall include only the last four digits of the credit or debit card or the bank account number used for payment of the covered account. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.7) Sec. 58-44. - Sources and types of red flags. All employees responsible for or involved in the process of opening a covered account, restoring a covered account or accepting payment for a covered account shall check for red flags as indicators of possible identity theft and such red flags may include: (1) Alerts from consumer reporting agencies, fraud detection agencies or service providers. Examples of alerts include but are not limited to: a. A fraud or active duty alert that is included with a consumer report; b. A notice of credit freeze in response to a request for a consumer report; c. A notice of address discrepancy provided by a consumer reporting agency; d. Indications of a pattern of activity in a consumer report that is inconsistent with the history and usual pattern of activity of an applicant or customer, such as: i. A recent and significant increase in the volume of inquiries; ii. An unusual number of recently established credit relationships; iii. A material change in the use of credit, especially with respect to recently established credit relationships; or iv. An account that was closed for cause or identified for abuse of account privileges by a financial institution or creditor. (2) Suspicious documents. Examples of suspicious documents include: a. Documents provided for identification that appear to be altered or forged; b. Identification on which the photograph or physical description is inconsistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer; c. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with information provided by the applicant or customer; d. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with readily accessible information that is on file with the county, such as a signature card or a recent check; or e. An application that appears to have been altered or forged, or appears to have been destroyed and reassembled. (3) Suspicious personal identification, such as a suspicious address change. Examples of suspicious identifying information include: a. Personal identifying information that is inconsistent with external information sources used by the county. For example: i. The address does not match any address in any available consumer report; or ii. The Social Security Number ("SSN") has not been issued, or is listed on the Social Security Administration's Death Master File. b. Personal identifying information provided by the customer is not consistent with other personal identifying information provided by the customer, such as a lack of correlation between the SSN range and date of birth. c. Personal identifying information or a phone number or address, is associated with known fraudulent applications or activities as indicated by internal or third-party sources used by the county. d. Other information provided, such as fictitious mailing address, mail drop addresses, jail addresses, invalid phone numbers, pager numbers or answering services, is associated with fraudulent activity. e. The SSN provided is the same as that submitted by other applicants or customers. f. The address or telephone number provided is the same as or similar to the account number or telephone number submitted by an unusually large number of applicants or customers. g. The applicant or customer fails to provide all required personal identifying information on an application or in response to notification that the application is incomplete. h. Personal identifying information is not consistent with personal identifying information that is on file with the county. i. The applicant or customer cannot provide authenticating information beyond that which generally would be available from a wallet or consumer report. (4) Unusual use of or suspicious activity relating to a covered account. Examples of suspicious activity include: a. Shortly following the notice of a change of address for an account, county receives a request for the addition of authorized users on the account. b. A new revolving credit account is used in a manner commonly associated with known patterns of fraud. For example, the customer fails to make the first payment or makes an initial payment but no subsequent payments. c. An account is used in a manner that is not consistent with established patterns of activity on the account. There is, for example: i. Nonpayment when there is no history of late or missed payments; ii. A material change in purchasing or spending patterns; d. An account that has been inactive for a long period of time is used (taking into consideration the type of account, the expected pattern of usage and other relevant factors). e. Mail sent to the customer is returned repeatedly as undeliverable although transactions continue to be conducted in connection with the customer's account. f. The county is notified that the customer is not receiving paper account statements. g. The county is notified of unauthorized charges or transactions in connection with a customer's account. h. The county is notified by a customer, law enforcement or another person that it has opened a fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity theft. (5) Notice from customers, law enforcement, victims or other reliable sources regarding possible identity theft or "phishing" relating to covered accounts. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.8) Sec. 58-45. - Prevention and mitigation of identity theft. (a) In the event that any county employee responsible for or involved in restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect to existing covered accounts, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to such employee's immediate supervisor. If, in his or her discretion, such immediate supervisor deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to the chairman or his/her designee, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the chairman or his/her designee in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary, a county employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the chairman or his/her designee: (1) Contact the customer; (2) Make the following changes to the account if, after contacting the customer, it is apparent that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's covered account: a. Change any account numbers, passwords, security codes, or other security devices that permit access to an account; or b. Close the account. (3) Cease attempts to collect additional charges from the customer and decline to sell the customer's account to a debt collector in the event that the customer's account has been accessed without authorization and such access has caused additional charges to accrue; (4) Notify a debt collector within a reasonable time, as determined by the chairman or his/her designee, of the discovery of likely or probable identity theft relating to a customer account that has been sold to such debt collector in the event that a customer's account has been sold to a debt collector prior to the discovery of the likelihood or probability of identity theft relating to such account; (5) Notify law enforcement, in the event that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's account causing additional charges to accrue or accessing personal identifying information; or (6) Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. (b) In the event that any county employee responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect an application for a new account, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to such employee's immediate supervisor. If, in his or her discretion, the immediate supervisor deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the immediate supervisor shall convey this information to the chairman or his/her designee, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the chairman or his/her designee in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary, a county employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the chairman or his/her designee: (1) Request additional identifying information from the applicant; (2) Deny the application for the new account; (3) Notify law enforcement of possible identity theft; or (4) Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.9) Sec. 58-46. - Updating the program. The board of commissioners shall annually review and, as deemed necessary by the board of commissioners, update the Identity Theft Prevention Program along with any relevant red flags in order to reflect changes in risks to customers or to the safety and soundness of the county and its covered accounts from identity theft. In so doing, the board of commissioners shall consider the following factors and exercise its discretion in amending the program: (1) The county's experiences with identity theft; (2) Updates in methods of identity theft; (3) Updates in customary methods used to detect, prevent, and mitigate identity theft; (4) Updates in the types of accounts that the county offers or maintains; and (5) Updates in service provider arrangements. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.10) Sec. 58-47. - Program administration. The chairman or his/her designee is responsible for oversight of the program and for program implementation. The chief financial officer is responsible for reviewing reports prepared by staff regarding compliance with red flag requirements and with recommending material changes to the program, as necessary in the opinion of the chief financial officer, to address changing identity theft risks and to identify new or discontinued types of covered accounts. Any recommended material changes to the program shall be submitted to the board of commissioners for its consideration. (1) The chairman or his/her designee will report to the chief financial officer at least annually, on compliance with the red flag requirements. The report will address material matters related to the program and evaluate issues such as: a. The effectiveness of the policies and procedures of the county in addressing the risk of identity theft in connection with the opening of covered accounts and with respect to existing covered accounts; b. Service provider arrangements; c. Significant incidents involving identity theft and management's response; and d. Recommendations for material changes to the program. (2) The chairman or his/her designee is responsible for providing training to all employees responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account with respect to the implementation and requirements of the Identity Theft Prevention Program. The chairman or his/her designee shall exercise his or her discretion in determining the amount and substance of training necessary. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.11) Sec. 58-48. - Outside service providers. In the event that the county engages a service provider to perform an activity in connection with one or more covered accounts the chairman or his/her designee shall exercise his or her discretion in reviewing such arrangements in order to ensure, to the best of his or her ability, that the service provider's activities are conducted in accordance with policies and procedures, agreed upon by written contract, that are designed to detect any red flags that may arise in the performance of the service provider's activities and take appropriate steps to prevent or mitigate identity theft. (Res. of 4-28-2009, § 1.12) Sec. 58-49. - Utilities and medical services billing. (a) The Identity Theft Prevention Program is to include application to the management of customer accounts for Emergency Medical Services. (b) The Identity Theft Prevention Program is to include application to the management of any customer accounts that may now exist or be created in the future. (Res. of June 9, 2009) Editor's note— A resolution adopted June 9, 2009, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion as § 58-49 was at the discretion of the editor.

div.head: Chapter 62 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Establishment of recreation systems, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-64-1 et seq.; power to provide parks, recreational areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 62-1—62-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BARROW COUNTY PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. State Law reference— Parks and recreation board, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-5.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 62-31. - Name. The name of the board created by this article shall be "Barrow County Parks and Recreation Board". (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 1) Sec. 62-32. - Purpose. The purpose of the parks and recreation board is to carry on a recreation program. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 3(1)) Sec. 62-33. - Composition; appointment. The membership of the county parks and recreation board shall consist of seven persons appointed by the board of commissioners. A general guideline regarding members of the board shall be one member from each commission district and one member at large. All members shall be selected without regard to race, sex, religion or national origin. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 2A) Sec. 62-34. - Terms. For the appointment of the initial members of the parks and recreation board, three members, appointed by commission districts 1, 2 and 3, will have one-year terms; two members, appointed by commission districts 4 and 5, will have two-year terms; and two members, appointed by commission district 6 and the chairman of the board of commissioners, will have three-year terms. Thereafter, all members of the board shall serve for terms of three years. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 2A) Sec. 62-35. - Compensation. All seven members of the parks and recreation board shall serve on a voluntary basis and without remuneration of any kind. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 2A) Sec. 62-36. - Ex officio members. The board of commissioners shall serve as ex officio members of the parks and recreation board without a vote. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 2A) Sec. 62-37. - Nominations for appointment. The parks and recreation board shall have the privilege of submitting to the board of commissioners such names of persons for appointment they feel are suitable, but there shall be nothing binding on the board of commissioners in these appointments suggestions. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 2A) Sec. 62-38. - Reappointment; removal. Persons appointed to the parks and recreation board may be reappointed by the board of commissioners on expiration of a term on the board. However, any appointee to the board may be removed, by the commissioner who made the appointment, for cause. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 2A) Sec. 62-39. - Resignations. Resignations from the parks and recreation board shall be tendered in writing to the board of commissioners, with a copy thereof to the chairperson of the board. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 2B) Sec. 62-40. - Vacancies. The absence from three consecutive regular meetings by any member of the parks and recreation board, without due cause, shall constitute a vacancy on the parks and recreation board. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 8E) Sec. 62-41. - Filling vacancies. The board of commissioners shall move expediently to appoint a new member to fill an unexpired term. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 2B) Sec. 62-42. - General responsibilities. The parks and recreation board shall formulate, implement, operate, administer, and maintain such recreation program to the best interest of all county citizens, expending such sums as are appropriated for its purposes by the county governing bodies, with such expenditures subject to the approval of the board of commissioners. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 3(2)) Sec. 62-43. - Expansion of facilities. The parks and recreation board, subject to the approval and direction of the board of commissioners, shall provide for expansion of facilities open to all citizens of the county. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 3(3)) Sec. 62-44. - Statutory powers; duties. The parks and recreation board shall be vested, except as restricted herein, with all powers and duties as granted under O.C.G.A. § 36-64-3, as it now exists, or as it may hereafter be amended. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 5(1)) Sec. 62-45. - Budget. The parks and recreation board and director shall, each year, timely submit to the governing body of the county a budget for the administration, operation and maintenance of the recreation program and showing expected expenditures in each of the recreation areas. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 5(2)) Sec. 62-46. - Fees, charges. The parks and recreation board is empowered to establish, revise and collect fees and rentals for the use of recreation areas and to impose and set requirements governing such use. Accurate records of such fees shall be always maintained and open to inspection by the county governing bodies. Anticipated fees shall be accounted for in the annual budget. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 5(3)) Sec. 62-47. - Reports to governing bodies. The parks and recreation board shall periodically report to the governing bodies in the county the condition of the respective lands and capital improvements thereof, and shall immediately notify such bodies of any damage thereto or condition requiring repair and make recommendations concerning such condition and/or required repairs. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 5(4)) Sec. 62-48. - Amendments. The bylaws of the parks and recreation board may be amended with a simple majority vote of a quorum of the membership at any meeting, provided notification of the bylaws change has been given to the membership at the meeting prior to the meeting at which the bylaws amendment is voted on. This approved amendment is a recommendation to the board of commissioners for adoption. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 9) Secs. 62-49—62-70. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
Sec. 62-71. - Organization. The parks and recreation board shall elect its chairman, and such officers as are necessary, from among its appointed members. The terms of the chairman and such other officers shall be one year, or until their successors are duly elected and qualified. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 4(1)) Sec. 62-72. - Officers. The officers of the parks and recreation board shall be chairperson, vice-chairperson, secretary and treasurer. These officers shall be elected from the parks and recreation board members by a majority vote of the parks and recreation board members present and voting. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 7) Sec. 62-73. - Selection. The officers of the parks and recreation board shall be elected by secret ballot annually, and shall serve for the term of one-year, not to exceed two consecutive terms. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 7) Sec. 62-74. - Chairperson. The chairperson of the parks and recreation board shall be responsible for presiding at all parks and recreation board meetings; shall serve as parks and recreation board liaison between the parks and recreation board and the board of commissioners and other funding agencies; shall be spokesperson for the parks and recreation board voicing those policies of the parks and recreation board which have been determined by a majority vote of the parks and recreation board; shall appoint such standing committees or temporary committees as the chairperson deems necessary to the efficient operation of the business of the parks and recreation board; shall be responsible for making an annual report on the parks and recreation board to the board of commissioners. The director and other officers of the parks and recreation board shall assist the chairperson in compiling this report which shall cover financial as well as activities of the recreation program. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 7) Sec. 62-75. - Vice-chairperson. The vice-chairperson shall preside at any meetings from which the chairperson must be absent; shall assist the chairperson in any of the chairperson's duties, where necessary; shall be responsible for taking an interested oversight in the general activities of the recreation program; and shall assist the director in an advisory capacity, wherever needed and/or requested in improving activities already in the program or in adding new activity areas to the existing program. The vice-chairperson shall become the chairperson, should that office become vacant by resignation or otherwise. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 7) Sec. 62-76. - Secretary. The parks and recreation board shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the county, or of the parks and recreation board. The secretary shall be responsible for taking the minutes of each parks and recreation board meeting; shall assist the chairperson in compiling the annual report (a copy of which shall be attached to that year's minutes as a permanent reference); and perform such other functions as may be required of the secretary. (Res. of 2-11-1997, §§ 4(2), 7) Sec. 62-77. - Treasurer. The treasurer shall receive all monies for the parks and recreation board and deposit all monies in such depositories as the parks and recreation board may direct; shall pay all bills and charges approved by the parks and recreation board; shall render to the parks and recreation board a financial statement at such intervals as the parks and recreation board may direct; shall itemize the expenses and income for the period reported; and shall attend to such other duties as may be assigned by the chairperson. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 7) Sec. 62-78. - Recreation director. (a) The board of commissioners shall appoint a recreation director and such other staff and employees as it may deem necessary to properly and adequately conduct the recreation program. However, the salaries of such officers and employees shall be within and consistent with the budget established and approved. All such personnel shall be subject to the personnel plan of the county. (b) The duties of the director shall be to plan, organize, direct and control a countywide recreation program, pursuant to the policy established by the board of commissioners and within the budget submitted to and approved by the county's governing bodies. The director shall report all progress on activities to the parks and recreation board as requested by the board of commissioners. Checks issued by the parks and recreation board shall require the signature of the director and the chairperson of the parks and recreation board. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 6) Secs. 62-79—62-100. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - MEETINGS
Sec. 62-101. - Regular meetings. The parks and recreation board shall hold regular bimonthly meetings at a time and place to be designated by the parks and recreation board. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 8A) Sec. 62-102. - Special meetings. Special meetings of the parks and recreation board may be called by the chairperson at the request of three members of the parks and recreation board. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 8B) Sec. 62-103. - Quorum. A quorum of the parks and recreation board shall consist of four members for any meeting of the parks and recreation board. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 8C) Sec. 62-104. - Minutes. Minutes of all meetings of the parks and recreation board shall be taken to reflect an accurate reporting of the business conducted. These minutes shall be available to all persons and organizations upon request. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 8D) Sec. 62-105. - Annual meeting. The annual meeting of the parks and recreation board shall be held at the September meeting each year. At this meeting the officers shall be elected for the coming year. (Res. of 2-11-1997, § 8E) Sec. 62-106. - Rules of procedure. The parks and recreation board shall make its own rules of procedure, consistent with state law and the authority granted it by resolution of the county. Generally, the procedure at meetings of the parks and recreation board shall be governed by the latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. (Res. of 2-11-1997, §§ 4(3), 10)

div.head: Chapter 66 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance pertaining to land use, development regulations or zoning saved from repeal, § 1-10(7); any ordinance relating to subdivisions or dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the county saved from repeal, § 1-10(10); administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; planning committee, §§ 30-91 et seq.; environment, ch. 38; flood hazard prevention, ch. 46; manufactured homes and mobile homes, ch. 54; roads, ch. 70; signs, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 90; zoning, app. A; development standards for zoning, app. A, art. V; development regulations, app. B; plan and plat specifications for development regulations, app. B, art. 7; general requirements for planned development, app. B, § 8.5. State Law reference— Coordinated and comprehensive planning and service delivery by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-70-1 et seq.; automatic membership of counties and municipalities in regional development centers, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-33.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 66-1. - Comprehensive plan adopted. The county board of commissioners resolves that the joint city/county comprehensive plan for the county and the cities of Auburn, Bethlehem, Carl, Russell, Statham and Winder, dated June 1992 and as approved by the state department of community affairs, is hereby adopted. (Code 1993, § 17-1) State Law reference— Automatic membership of counties and municipalities in regional development centers, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-33. Sec. 66-2. - Fees for development permits and approvals. Charges for licenses, permits, and other approvals required to be obtained shall be in amounts as established and amended from time to time by the director of the planning department, upon the written approval of the chairman of the board of commissioners and the chief of operations; provided, however, that the amount of such fees shall be presented within the annual budget approved by the board of commissioners. In the event that the position of director of the planning department is vacant, the amount of the fees may be established and amended from time to time by the chief of operations, upon the written approval of the chairman of the board of commissioners; provided, however, that the amount of such fees shall be presented within the annual budget approved by the board of commissioners. (Code 1993, § 17-2; Ord. of 5-10-2005) State Law reference— Approval of plat of subdivision prior to recording, O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67(d). Sec. 66-3. - Land use dispute resolution process. (a) Prior to initiating any formal annexation activities, the city will notify the county planning department in writing by certified mail, return receipt requested of a proposed annexation and provide information on location of property, size of area and proposed land use and zoning classifications of the property upon annexation.
